Fields.DialogueText: Your new glasses have just arrived. Here, why don't you try them on?
Ah, Captain, thank you. I've been waiting for these for some time.
Ursula, there you are! Am I interrupting?
Not at all, Captain. The crew were just regaling me with stories about some of their adventures.
How are they?
Yes, very satisfactory. I should be able to better scout enemies with these by my side.

Fields.MenuText: I've never met a Belle with poor eyesight before. Is it common?
Has your eyesight ever been a detriment on the battlefield before?
Quick! Take them off and tell me; how many fingers am I holding up?

Fields.DialogueText: Belles come in all shapes and sizes, Captain. To my knowledge, I am the first of my kind but I'd be happy to compile some research for you during my break.
I... have been known to miss a torpedo... or two...
Captain this is no time for... did you always have seven fingers?
*ALARM*
What say we test these glasses out on some Morganas?
As you wish, Captain.
@BATTLE
I have to say, Ursula, those glasses really suit you.
I appreciate your concern for my eyesight, Captain. I will admit, there is another reason why I wished to purchase these.
Oh, yeah?
I enjoy the way they shape my face. I'm constantly mistaken for being far younger than I actually am. I'd hoped these would add a layer of wisdom to my youthful eyes.
Hmm, I can't really tell the difference, to be honest!
Captain...

Although, one thing is for certain. Those glasses definitely enhance your pointed eyelids. They really do look like icicles! This cold stare is one of the more freezing looks I've received in a while.
Well, it appears that my efforts have been fruitless. I'll adjourn to my room for now but perhaps we may reconvene again at your earliest convenience.
Ursula! One last thing before you go!
Yes, Captain?
Last chance. How many fingers?
What are you reading there, Ursula?
Pay me no mind, Captain. I've fulfilled my duties for the day and am simply partaking in a brief respite. Fret not, I haven't been shirking my responsibilities.
No, no, I wasn't thinking anything of the sort. I was just curious.
I see. In that case, I'd be happy to describe it to you. The protagonist is a pulchritudinous young girl who has an unfortunate encounter with a tergiversant con-man.
*sigh* So it's hopeless after all.
What's going on, Ursula? I'm lost.
Well, as per your remark, the glasses failed at making me look more mature. So, I decided to do some reading.
And what exactly have you been reading?
... A thesaurus.
That's what it is! Now I understand.
In an effort to act more adult, I thought altering my vernacular... *ahem* changing the way I speak, would make me seem more... worldly.

Fields.MenuText: You don't need to push yourself so hard.
Have you always felt this way?
Are people belittling you?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps you're right, Captain. I'll keep that in mind.
Not inherently. It's unfortunate that I've made so many blunders already with regards to missing my targets. My looks coupled with my aim have labeled me as a younger sibling in need of protection.
I've always been aware of my looks in comparison to other Belles. My sisters command respect from their looks alone and, while I am happy for them, I must work that much harder.
Regardless, let's leave the Shakespeare at home, shall we?
Yes, Captain.
Try not to worry so much about what other people think. You take down Morganas twice your size every day. If that doesn't command respect, I don't know what does!
I never looked at it that way. Thank you, Captain.
*ALARM*
Just in time. There's your chance to prove yourself.
Yes, Captain. I won't let you down.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: A young what? A turkey who?
I don’t think you’re pronouncing those words the way they’re meant to be pronounced.
Please don't make me hit one or both of us with a dictionary.

Fields.DialogueText: Enjoying the fresh air, Ursula?
Yes, it's very pleasant.
Nothing like standing over the edge of a ship, looking out over the waves and soaking in the crisp sea breeze, am I right?
Yes, Captain.
... Let me put this differently. What makes you smile, Ursula?
Excuse me?
In all the time I've known you, you've yet to smile once!
Apologies, Captain. I'll do better to smile in your presence.
I don't want you to force it. Just do it naturally.
I'm not a very... "smiley" person, Captain. What kinds of things make you smile?

Fields.MenuText: Puppies?
Rainbows?
Your company?

Fields.DialogueText: A collection of air currents forming pretty colors in the sky is all it takes? Perhaps I'm not as immature as I thought...
I do enjoy petting and caring for animals but the discussion of such things is incomparable to the real thing.
... I'm not sure how you'd like me to respond to that.
There isn't a formula to happiness! "Me, Ursula. Me see clown. Activate joy receptors. Laughter mode engaged. HA HA HA HA. Laughter mode suspended."
Is that how you see me, Captain?
I tell you what. I'm going to get you to laugh and, when you do, you have to promise not to hold back in front of me again. Deal?
Ok, that sounds acceptable.
*ALARM*
I've got a PUNCHline or two I'd like to deliver to these Morganas, eh, Ursula?
Very witty, Captain. You are a phenomenal joke teller.
It's going to be a loooong war...
@BATTLE
Okay, Ursula. Knock knock.
Captain, I really don't think that--
Come on, just humor me. Knock-knock jokes are one of the great pillars of modern civilization.
... Very well. Who's there?

Fields.MenuText: Boo.
Cash.
Interrupting cow.

Fields.DialogueText: Boo who?
No need to cry, it's only a joke!
Cash who?
I prefer peanuts, actually!
Interrupting c--
MOOOOO!
I think your delivery might need some work, Captain.
Nothing, huh? Oh well, how about we head back inside. The Deck's just been swabbed and I can feel my grip slip--UWA!
*POMPF*
Owowow... look at that! A huge wet patch on my behind! I'll have to get changed as soon as... Ursula? Why are you looking at me like that?
It's... nothing, Captain. I... I just... HAHAHAHAHA!
This isn't exactly what I had in mind when I wanted to make you smile.
The fall was so sudden! And the wet patch! It's too much!
As much as you claim to be wiser beyond your years, your sense of humor isn't doing you any favors. Slapstick is the pinnacle of child comedy, you know?
*Ahem* Excuse me, Captain, I don't know what came over me.
Hey, none of that! Remember your promise. Loosen up a little from now on, all right? Even if it means laughing at your captain every now and again.
Yes, Captain!
*ALARM*
Those Morganas look so devoid of comedy, we may have to snap their funny bone as opposed to tickling it!
I'm right behind you, Captain. Actually, perhaps I should take the lead to cover your... never mind.
@BATTLE
Captain, I had something to ask you.
Sure. You can ask me anything.
I wanted to know if you know of any additional duties I might have the opportunity to add to my schedule.
Sorry, I must have misheard. You want to do... MORE work?
If possible.
Ursula... I don't know how to put this. You already fulfil the duties of at least five crew members all by yourself. Were I to give you any further duties, it'd feel like slave labor!
I see... Sorry for wasting your time.
Now, hang on a minute. What's this all about?
It's nothing, Captain. I just...
Did you forget our promise already? Speak up if you have something to say.
I just don't want to let anybody down...

Fields.MenuText: Do you mean the crew?
Do you mean the UK?
Do you mean your family?

Fields.DialogueText: In part. My class of submarine are relatively infantile *ahem* still quite young and so there is a lot riding on my performance. I need to make a good impression for my siblings.
I want nothing more for the UK to emerge from this war having suffered as little damage as possible. Were Cumbria to suffer any substantial damage I would never be able to forgive myself.
I haven't spent as much time as I would have liked to with Undine and Unity. Yet, their grace and temperament are second to none. For me to fail would be to spit in the face of all who respect them.
You're doing fine, Ursula. Just keep attending to your duties and trying to smile. That's enough for me.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Let's deal with them quickly, Ursula!
@BATTLE
What a refreshing breeze!
It's the same wind whether we're on the ship or not, isn't it?
No, Captain, you couldn't be more wrong. This wind is much more effervescent *ahem* genteel *ahem* nice...
*RUFF*
What was that? Did you hear that, Captain?
I think you've found a new friend. Take a look down.
What's the matter, Ursula? Are you not a dog kind of per--
He's the most adorable thing I've ever seen in my entire life!
Hello! Aren't you handsome! Yes you are! Yes you are, you're my handsome boy!
The ice queen melts! I may have to take up barking myself if it leads to this kind of treatment.
I think he's a stray, Captain. Can we keep him, can we keep him, huh, huh?!
I don't know... a dog is a lot of responsibility...
I promise I'll walk him, and feed him, and pick up after him! You won't have to lift a finger.
I tell you what, if you can take out these encroaching Morganas, you can keep him.
I won't let you down, Captain! And I definitely won't let you down, Churchill!
Churchill?
*WAN*
@BATTLE
Watch this, Captain. I've been teaching him some new tricks.
Really? I'm surprised you managed to train a puppy so obediently.
Okay, Churchill! Speak!
*WAN*
Stay still and speak!
*WAN*
Blink and speak!
*WAN*
Not too shabby, am I right, Captain?
It's... uh... definitely something.
Animals are so precious to this world. I'm relieved this little guy has finally found a home where he belongs.

Fields.MenuText: Why do you love animals so much?
Does one stray mean that much to you?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Captain! I myself am but a puppy in the world of Belles. Were I to be cast aside without being given the chance to reach my full potential I would be heartbroken.

Fields.MenuText: I haven't seen you this fired up in... EVER!

Fields.DialogueText: *Ahem* Just because I'm thorough and clinical doesn't mean I don't have a heart, Captain...
You know, I'm not really sure. Perhaps it's because my name holds the meaning of "Little Bear" but, whenever I see an animal, something switches in my brain and I can't control myself.
Well, I'm happy that you finally have someone to lighten your mood.
Perhaps you'd like to join us some time, Captain. You've seen how brilliant I am at teaching Churchill here. I'm sure I could whip you into shape in no time.
*ALARM*
What's the expression? "You can't teach an old Captain new tricks but together you can take down some Morganas?"
You might be paraphrasing slightly, but I believe it's something along those lines. Let's get ready, Captain!
@BATTLE
Afternoon, Ursula. Churchill not with you today?
I've loaned him out to the crew for the day. They say petting an animal soothes the soul.
I didn't think a logician such as yourself would be superstitious.
I don't particularly believe in all of them but they are truly fascinating. I'm very much looking forward to crossing the equator for the first time and joining the ranks of seasoned sailors.

Fields.MenuText: Huh. Do you know a lot of... well, naval superstitions?

Fields.DialogueText: A few - naval and British both, thanks to a long letter from Edinburgh. Most seem to be linked to bad luck. Opening an umbrella indoors, seeing a sole magpie, walking under a ladder...

Fields.MenuText: Are you well traveled?

Fields.DialogueText: Not particularly. I've spent most of my life close to Britain so this voyage is truly special to me.

Fields.MenuText: How will you celebrate such an event?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... Perhaps, for such a special occassion, I could allow myself a second slice of sponge cake.
Well, while we wait to reach the equator, would you like to partake in a few rituals here and now? I think I can remember a few.
Really?! *Ahem* I mean, that sounds very enjoyable, Captain. I appreciate you taking the time to humour me.
*ALARM*
Looks like this ritual is going to require a sacrifice.
Morganas! Steadily encroaching!
Let's deal with them quickly, Ursula!
Yes, Captain!
@BATTLE
Okay, Ursula. This here is an old Scottish tradition - you're not the only one who gets letters from Edinburgh.
Yes, Captain.
You see, on days where fishing seems next to impossible, it's important to lure one's food out by any means possible.
I understand.
So, what they used to do, as a form of hazing, was throw a man overboard and haul him back up to encourage the fish to school around our boat!
I see. Fascinating.
I thought we could try that now, while we're docked. Small fish sometimes swim up close to the ships so we might be able to catch something!
That sounds like an excellent idea, Captain.
Luckily, I've got this stuffed toy sailor with me. By using this little fella, we won't have to push anyone into-- why are you looking at me like that, Ursula?
*SPLOOOSH*
Can you see any fish down there, Captain?
Blubblublublublbulbu
I don't think this ritual holds much weight, if I'm honest.

Fields.MenuText: Help me out!
Why did you do that?!

Fields.DialogueText: You were the one who wanted to test this ritual. I was just speeding things along.
You haven't even tried to look for any fish. Will you give up on your own ritual so easily?

Fields.MenuText: We could have used the teddy!

Fields.DialogueText: How dare you insult the intelligence of marine life so lackadaisically *ahem* brazenly, Captain! All animals, including fish, would not be fooled by your tricks so easily.
It's f-f-freezing!
What was that, Captain? You'd like me to take out these Morganas while you crawl back to shore?
For someone so cold, you seem to be enjoying this more than you should be.
As you wish, Captain. I'll handle these Morganas for you. Perhaps, while you dry off, you could think of another ritual for us to try.
@BATTLE
Are you all right, Captain?
Apologies, I could sense that Churchill was hungry and so I had to rush off to feed him. You understand.
Right... Well, I've been doing some thinking, and there's another ritual that has leapt to mind.
I'm all ears.
I'm not sure if you know this but, aboard ships, bananas are considered bad luck.
No, I wasn't aware, Captain.
So, when faced with a large cargo of bananas, many crews would simply toss them overboard.
What a waste.
My point exactly. So, if you need to remove such a large quantitiy of bananas from your ship, but don't want to waste their value in providing energy, what should you do?
Eat them?
Exactly! So, Ursula, I am challenging YOU to a banana eating contest!
I see. I suppose, if it's for research purposes, I could participate.
Wonderful! You don't know what you're in for, Ursula! I'm going to eat you under the table!
*ALARM*
Let's deal with these Morganas first to avoid any distractions. Perhaps I could bring any leftover bananas for Churchill! He'll be so pleased!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I am now. No thanks to you, I might add.
What, after the dunking the other day? Sure. I was probably still a full fifteen seconds away from hypothermia when the crew finally got me a towel.
Let this glare be my answer.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you all right, Captain? You're looking a little... yellow.
I don't need your pity! How many bananas are we at now?
Seventeen.
Seventeen?! Seventeen?! And you're not even fazed?!
I exert a lot of energy on the battlefield, Captain. My metabolism is very speedy.
Look at this! Look at this banana belly! Where on Earth are you putting it all!
If you'd like to stop, Captain, I'm sure Churchill could help you finish your share.
Please! I'm three times banana eating champion and I'm not going to be done in by the likes of you!
I will admit, I am very partial to fruit. I once tried to grow my own food in a garden but to no avail.

Fields.MenuText: What did you try to grow?
Why did you try to do that?

Fields.DialogueText: I enjoy nurturing things, I suppose. Whether it be animals, plant life, my juniors, or my country, I live to protect and serve.
Locust berries mostly but they require so much care and attention that I couldn't keep up. By comparison, Churchill may as well be a piece of furniture with the amount of care he requires.

Fields.MenuText: Is there a fruit most associated with the UK?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, despite my accent, I'm not actually Welsh. Were I to be, I would have said the Dragon Fruit. However, famous fruit in Cornwall is perhaps the Red Apple or Victoria Plum. Both are delicious!
One... more... bite!
*ALARM*
Captain! There's no time! Morganas inbound!
I'm right behind you, Ursula!
*WALKING*
Actually, I'll be about a quarter of a mile behind you at this rate. *BUURP* Something's going to explode in this battle and I DON'T think it's going to be the Morganas!
@BATTLE
*PSHHHHHHH*
Ursula! There you are! What are you doing out here? It's tipping down!
What's that, Captain? I can't hear you! You'll have to come out here in the rain!
Haven't you already gotten me wet enough recently?!
I... CAN'T... HEAR... YOU!
The things I do for this girl.
*CLOMP CLOMP CLOMP*
*KSHHHHHHHH*
I said; what are you doing out here?!
Captain! Isn't it wonderful!
Not the exact word I would choose...
It reminds me of home!

Fields.MenuText: Is the UK really this stormy?

Fields.DialogueText: Most days to be honest. Winter lasts from about November to April, Spring lasts May to July, Summer can be found for a brief week or two in August, and then Autumn will run until November.
Rest assured, whatever the season, it will be raining all the while!

Fields.MenuText: You're joking! This storm is biblical!

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I'm exaggerating but feeling the rain on my skin takes my mind back to my days in Cornwall.

Fields.MenuText: Are you homesick?

Fields.DialogueText: No, no, Captain. I love my home with all my heart but I was always meant to travel the globe. I can feel it resonating inside of me.
Hang on, let me get an umbrella.
No need, Captain, all my umbrellas are broken from venturing out into conditions like these.
Then throw them out!
Just because something has made a mistake or two, doesn't mean it won't have it's time to shine one day. What if I had been discarded so flippantly after missing my first torpedo?
Besides, you're sailing with a true blue Brit. We Brits never carry umbrellas; they're too much hassle!
So what do you do instead?
Whatever else, Captain? We get wet!
Ursula... it may just be my imagination but... I feel like I'm seeing an entirely new side to you lately.
It's chucklesome *ahem* funny, Captain. Ever since we had our talk... I've been feeling the same way.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Are you with me, Ursula!
I'm ready, Captain! Let's go!
@BATTLE
It looks like the storm has subsided, huh, Captain?
Thank goodness. If Britain is as rainy as that these days then I think I'll stick to the high seas.
Excuse me...
Hello, there. Are you okay, sweetheart?
I... um... was walking with my mummy and daddy and... um... I don't know where...*sniff*
Oh, you poor thing! Come here. Captain, we need to find this child's parents.
I'm sure, they're around her somewhere. Couldn't we just alert the authorities and...
*GLAAAAAAAAAAAAAARE*
S-sure, sweetie, we'll help you find your parents. What's your name?
It's Mary...
Ok, then, Mary - could you tell us where you last--
I don't like that person, Miss, can I talk to you instead?
Don't feel bad, Mary. You're not alone in that way of thinking. Come along, Captain, but leave the talking to me.
... How can she not like me? Ursula, stop joking around, you like me. People like me, right? Right?! Ursula!
Ok, Mary, could you tell us where you last saw your parents?
It was over there! By the flower stand!
I see. In that case, they couldn't have gone too far - hopefully close enough to the ship that I can help in the search. Captain do you have any idea... Captain!
How can she not like me? I'm so darn loveable--what?! Oh, sorry! I'm listening!
Mary's parents must still be in the port's Belle-friendly shopping zone. They probably panicked and attempted to retrace their steps too much.
Mummy and Daddy are always together and always smiling! I don't want them to be sad.
They won't be sad, Mary. People who are in love can never go too long without smiling.
So you aren't in love with that person over there?
M-M-M-Mary! That is my captain! I could never... we would never... Captain, can you speak with this child?!
Oh, so now she's my child too? I work hard all day and this is what I have to come back to? A girl who hates me and a Belle who won't stop shouting?
Are you saying I don't work hard?! My job is just as demanding as yours, Captain! Plus, I'm forced to take care of the child!
I never asked for this, you know.
You don't think I had dreams too. I wanted to visit that quaint little patisserie on the corner during our time on land. But I accepted the responsibility of caring for Mary and you should too!
Now you two sound like Uncle John and Auntie Eva. *teehee*
Ursula, wait. I think I can see Morganas encroaching on the dock.
I see them too. Mary, darling, you need to stay with this person for a while now, okay? I need to go do adult things.
Now you sound like Mummy on Daddy's birthday!
Ursula? You all right there? Your face looks a bit red.
*Ahem* P-p-p-perfectly fine, Captain. Morganas you say? I'll be off then!
@BATTLE
We've been looking for hours. Where on Earth could they be?

Fields.MenuText: Could you tell us what your parents look like again?
Is there anywhere we haven't looked yet?
Maybe Mary is a figment of our imagination.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think she fits the description of a typical siren, Captain...
I can't think of anywhere at all...
Daddy is quite tall but Mummy is shorter than him. Oh! and Daddy likes beans on toast!
This is hopeless...
Wait! There they are! Mummy! Daddy!
Wait, Mary, come back!
Let her go, Ursula. It's time for her to leave the nest.
I... I thought I would have more time with her...
That's always the way. One minute they're interrupting your intermission from sailing, the next they're running off to escape from you and rejoin their real parents.
They grow up so fast!
*ALARM*
It seems like we've circled back round to the ship! I think I heard the Morgana alarm in the distance.
I did too. Quick, let's hurry back and deal with them!
@BATTLE
Captain?
*CRASH*
Everything all right, Ursula?
Perfectly fine, Captain.
*SLAM*
I was just wondering...
*BOOF*
If you'd seen...
*BANG*
My glasses.
*KABOOM*
Captain! I didn't bump into the torpedo firing rig, did I?
No, its just some Morganas in the distance.
Phew, it's just a monster ship whose sole purpose in life is to gun us down and send us to Davy Jones. What a relief.
@BATTLE
I've been looking for them for some time now.

Fields.MenuText: I see.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I don't.

Fields.MenuText: Where did you last see them?

Fields.DialogueText: On my face.

Fields.MenuText: Let's see if we can find them.

Fields.DialogueText: ... If you're trying to be clever, Captain, this isn't the time...
*ALARM*
Let's deal with these Morganas and then I'll help you look for them.
That's... not a Morgana. I just nearly beached myself.
Right. Gotta find those glasses.
This may be a really weird question, but... your human body obviously has ship aspects to it. I don't suppose there's any way we could adjust your eyes directly somehow? Focusing lenses or...
As stated before, Captain. It is important that both yourself and the crew recognize my maturity for what it is. The glasses provide my face with the years of wisdom it has earned.
... And... I'm too scared to touch my eyes...
Okay, glasses. What we need to do is retrace your steps. Where's the last place you remember having them?
I was in the Mess Hall with the crew.
Great, let's head over there and see if we can find any clues.
You sound exactly like Sherlock Holmes, Captain.
It's elementary, my dear Ursula.
*ALARM*
They aren't as discreet as Professor Moriarty but these Morganas are making it known they're just as dangerous.
Let's take them out quickly, Captain.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, that's fair.
Artificial lenses right on the eyes, though. Somebody's going to make a fortune with that one day.
I don't blame you.

Fields.DialogueText: Stop looking so dubious - it's a real thing. Our lunatic doctor tells me there's this Hungarian ophthamologist who's been working with shaped plastic that even human beings can wear on our eyeballs.
I never could see without my glasses. It was my one true weakness.
In a world of backstabbing, lying, and deceit, was I really considered the blind one?
Still, the Captain claimed to have a lead on my case.
But... it's hard to see this journey wrapping up nicely with a pretty pink bow tied on top. This world is truly hell.
Ursula, what on Earth are you doing?
I'm monologuing, Captain. If we are to play the role of detective and sidekick then it's only fitting.
Just tell me what you were doing here on the night of the incident.
Well, I was studying several of my textbooks. I enjoy reading them quickly and in succession so I can donate them to local schools afterward.

Fields.MenuText: What was the textbook about?
How many books do you donate regularly?
How long does it take you to finish a book?

Fields.DialogueText: Actually, this was... more of a biography of King George VI. He's a truly inspirational man that I find a lot of joy in learning more about.
As many as I can.
No longer than an hour or two. Less if it's positively engrossing *ahem* interesting.
So, you sat here, read your book and then what happened after?
I went onto the deck to catch the afternoon rainfall!
Then that's our next lead!
*ALARM*
Right after we take out these Morganas!
@BATTLE
Is anything coming back to you, Ursula?
I definitely still had my glasses on at this point. I remember because the rainfall was difficult to see through my dripping lenses. Although, the wind was strong, they might have fallen off.
Hmm... If we factor in the advent of rainfall, coupled with the gale-force winds... subtract the square root of pi... carry the two...
What if we just investigated that glass lens over there?
A single lens... which seems to be along the route to the Engine Room. One might note that such a lens of glass usually fits into a pair of glasses with removable lenses!
Mhm, mhm.
One then speculates that that lens of glass, meant for your glasses with lenses, will surely lead us to your glasses in no time! Ah, lucky lens!
As expected, Captain, it looks like you've nearly cracked the case.
*ALARM*
We'll deal with these Morganas then head down to the Engine Room next.
Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I hope so. The talking to myself is getting hard to sustain.
Damn. This is the most fun I've let myself have in ages.
You think a cracked glasses case is involved? Interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: Puns are beneath you.
I think it's become pretty evident by now that we've got a glasses thief on our hands.
Why would anyone want to steal something so trivial?
Good question, and one that we'll hopefully find out once we catch the culprit.
You've really slipped into your role as Sherlock quite nicely, Captain. As a Brit, I'm very proud!

Fields.MenuText: What do you like most about the UK?
What do you like least about the UK?

Fields.DialogueText: Probably our sense of humor. It's very dry, self-derogatory, sarcastic, and dark. One suspects it's a function of the weather. And perhaps the food. And-
Hmm... most would probably say the weather or the food but I'm partial to both. We are a nation of complainers though which sometimes irks me. "Summer is too hot and winter is too cold!"
Ursula! Over there, look!
What is that?
It looks like paint shavings. Probably from your glasses. They lead back upstairs. If we follow them, we might find our villain!
*ALARM*
Morganas approaching! Let's take them out and then close this case!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You haven't even seen me play the violin while I concentrate furiously.

Fields.DialogueText: A misfortune that will haunt me all my days, Captain.
Here we are.
Such insolence! To steal your glasses then hold up inside my quarters. I won't stand for this, let's open the door.
Captain! There they are on your desk! Oh, the paint is all scratched away and they're soaking wet.
I think we've found our culprit all right.
*ARF*
Churchill! Did you take these from the Deck during the rainstorm? That's a bad First Lord of the Admiralty! Very bad!
*Arrrr...*
Oh... I can't stay mad at you!
And thus closes the books on another thrilling tale of Ursula and her Captain.
Whatever escapades will they get up to next?
Captain, please stop talking to yourself. You sound deranged.
*ALARM*
Hell. Now that you've got your glasses back, what say we test them out on some Morganas?
I can't think of any better targer practice. You stay here, Churchill. Mummy needs to go and violently incinerate a naval fleet, okay?
@BATTLE
You say that, but I saw you-
Hi, Ursula. Any reason you're sitting on the floor?
The crew were discussing something I had little interest in, so I wanted to distance myself from the conversation without distancing myself from them entirely.
You're not doing your maturity perception any favors, are you?
Actually, Captain, I've decided that caring about what others think of my looks is irrelevant. I will let my actions speak for themselves.
That's... the most mature thing I've heard anyone say in all my years as a captain. Good for you, Ursula.
Would you care to join me down here?
You know what, I think I will.
Would you like to see this textbook I've been reading recently. It's about the ASDIC.

Fields.MenuText: Anatomically Submerged Destroyers Initiate Carnage?

Fields.DialogueText: ... I'm impressed, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: What's that?

Fields.DialogueText: Let me explain, it's truly fascinating.

Fields.MenuText: You prefer non-fiction over fiction?

Fields.DialogueText: I like both and the UK is no stranger to famous wordsmiths. Dickens, Austen, Wordsworth; to name a few. Yet, I relish *ahem* really enjoy learning about new things.
The ASDIC was designed as a sonar system to detect objects underwater.
And that seems to have worked out rather well.
We Brits have always had a way with inventing. I'd like to create something like that one day.
Any ideas what?
Not yet but, whatever it is, I want it to make people's lives easier. That's what invention is all about at the end of the day. Filling a gap in the problems people face everyday.
*ALARM*
I don't suppose you could invent a way to quickly dispatch Morganas?
Captain, you're already looking at such an invention! Let's hurry!
@BATTLE
That breeze feels nice on your face, doesn't it, Ursula?
Yes, Captain. It really is incandescent *ahem I mean; enlivening *ahem* I mean... nice...
That thesaurus you read really did a number on you, huh?
I memorized so many words and while some do slip out on occasion, it feels like a waste not not utlilize all that information.

Fields.MenuText: Did you find a synonym that was particularly interesting?
Are there any words native to the UK that tickle your fancy?
Perhaps you could find work as a lexicographer.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm, one word I found which meant "to estimate something as worthless" was *ahem* floccinaucinihilipilification! Try saying that five times in ten seconds.
As you know, Shakespeare was a knack for creating his own words. "Amazing, cold-blooded..." He also invented several expressions such as "in a pickle." He was truly a genius.
I'm not sure about that, Captain. Maybe if, one day, someone invented a show about rearranging letters to form, let's say, nine letter words to a time limit, then I could find a job.
*ALARM*
Come on, Ursula! Let's whip these Morganas into shape!
Yes, Captain!
@BATTLE
Maybe there's a way we can retrain your mind to speak normally.
I'd love to try, Captain. Sometimes, when I think of the time lost to using so many syllables, it makes me think of all the work I am missing out on.
Why don't you try only using simple words that directly express how you feel?
... Hungry.
Exactly! Just like that!
Hungry!
Oh, okay, got it...
*ALARM*
Will medium-rare Morgana satisfy that hunger pang?
Kill. Eat. Captain.
I hope you're missing out a fair few words there, Ursula...
@BATTLE
Okay, Ursula; tell me how you feel.
Good.
Just good?
Great.
Why?
Captain.
Me?
Good.
Because I'm a good, Captain?
(Because, for the first time in my life, I feel a sense of belonging! Not one to be cast aside so frivolously, I was taken in and nurtured by your hands.)
(Erasing my prior transgressions without a second thought. I am eternally grateful.)
Yes.
Well, thanks a lot, Ursula. That means a lot to me.
... Upstairs.
You want to go with me to the Deck?
*SPRINTING*

Fields.MenuText: That's... one way of looking at it.
Not everything has to be about work, Ursula.
Okay, then.

Fields.DialogueText: Very perspicacious *ahem* insightful, Captain.
So, Ursula, what did you want to talk with me about?
I'll have to use my full vocabulary to express this.
Sure, go ahead.
I just wanted to thank you, Captain. I know I can be cold at times but, when you're a submarine, it isn't necessary or wise to raise one's temperature so easily. The fish around you would boil.
I know it must be hard for you, Ursula. You don't need to do all this.

Fields.MenuText: I'll always be there to help you.
I want you forever at my side.

Fields.DialogueText: Still. My glasses, my dog, my speech therapy lessons. I've always been fearful that one mistake would be the end of me but now I'm not so sure.
*ALARM*
Hold that thought, Ursula. Let's deal with these Morganas then you can finish what you were saying.
@BATTLE
I didn't have much else to say... but I wanted to thank you for always being there for me.
You don't need to thank me for doing something so obvious! I want the Ursula full package under my command, not some censored and watered-down version. Please, rest assured...
I know I can rely on you, Captain!
Captain... For the first time since I finished that thesaurus... I'm at a loss for words.
